newsitem.title: HONG KONG: Hong Kong stocks bound up in early morning trade.
newsitem.headline: Hong Kong stocks bound up in early morning trade.

text.p: Hong Kong stocks jumped ahead in early Tuesday morning trade, on good liquidity and buying interest in the index's heavy weight counters, brokers said.
"We are seeing some follow through buying from yesterday,"said one broker with a large Asian house."We should end the morning 50 to 60 points up."
The Hang Seng Index put on 76 points to trade at 13,407, after a weak opening saw the index dip to a low of 13,278.06. Turnover was a healthy HK$1.20 billion after 30 minutes.
"It looks like some year end bonus money is going into HSBC," said the broker.
Property stocks led the market's 200-point rise on Monday, but finance counters, chiefly HSBC Holdings, were the stars on Tuesday.

HSBC Holdings added HK$1.50 to HK$163.50 and subsidiary Hang Seng Bank HK$0.75 to HK$93.50. Bank of East Asia put on HK$0.30 before easing to trade up HK$0.10 at HK$34.40.The sector leads off the annual reporting season beginning in mid-January, brokers pointed out.
The market's early strength took many brokers by surprise.
"We thought it would be a quiet day," said Ronald Lam, chief dealer at Dao Heng Securities.
"There are no bad factors, only positive news," said Lam, adding investors were showing renewed confidence in the property sector.
Cheung Kong led the sector with a gain of HK$0.25 to HK$69.00 while other counters came in for profit-taking.
Great Eagle slid HK$0.40 to HK$32.50 and Hang Lung shed HK$0.35 to HK$16.85. Amoy Properties bucked the trend putting on HK$0.15 to HK$11.15.
Red chip Shanghai Industrial showed the second best gain after HSBC with a rise of HK$0.60 to HK$25.80.
December Hang Seng Index futures, which had traded up 75 points to a high of 13,525, eased in mid-morning trade to 13,465, a 10-point gain.
The March contract was trading at a day high, 60 points up at 13,630.
